question.title: When some test suites exist in a module, how may I ask maven failsafe to run only them (they are running test cases) and not them and the test cases?
question.body:
If I run it with an assemblage profile, my Maven runs a failsafe plugin when encountering a file ending with IT, and that's what I was willing until now:

<profile>
    <id>default</id>

    <activation>
        <activeByDefault>true</activeByDefault>
    </activation>

    <properties>
        <skip.integration.tests>true</skip.integration.tests>
        <skip.unit.tests>false</skip.unit.tests>
    </properties>
</profile>

<profile>
    <id>assemblage</id>

    <properties>
        <skip.integration.tests>false</skip.integration.tests>
        <skip.unit.tests>false</skip.unit.tests>
    </properties>

    <build>
        <plugins>
            <plugin>
                <groupId>org.apache.maven.plugins</groupId>
                <artifactId>maven-failsafe-plugin</artifactId>

                <configuration>
                    <skipTests>${skip.integration.tests}</skipTests>
                </configuration>
            </plugin>
        </plugins>
    </build>
</profile>

<plugin>
    <groupId>org.apache.maven.plugins</groupId>
    <artifactId>maven-surefire-plugin</artifactId>
    <version>${surefire-version}</version>

    <configuration>
        <skipTests>${skip.unit.tests}</skipTests>

        <excludes>
            <exclude>**/IT*.java</exclude>
        </excludes>
    </configuration>
</plugin>

My modules have some unit tests and IT test cases. And now some (but not all modules) have also test suites:

ls */*IT*
cog/CogSuiteIT.java      

cog/DepartementsITCase.java         
cog/RegionsITCase.java         
cog/CommunesITCase.java  
cog/EvenementsCommunauxITCase.java  
cog/SirenCommunauxITCase.java  

competence/CompetenceITCase.java
groupement/GroupementsPerimetresITCase.java

A test suite is here to set the order of execution of assembly/integration test cases [that are in my project stateful by choice], to optimize their execution speed.

@Suite
@SelectClasses({
   RegionsITCase.class, DepartementsITCase.class, SirenCommunauxITCase.class, 
   CommunesITCase.class, EvenementsCommunauxITCase.class
})
@DisplayName("Code Officiel Géographique")
public class CogSuiteIT {
}

My problem: if I run a mvn install -Passemblage | grep -F 'IT' | grep -F 'Tests run' here's what I see:

[INFO] Tests run: [...] Time elapsed: 30.522 s - in [*].CompetenceITCase
[INFO] Tests run: [...] Time elapsed: 242.972 s - in [*].CommunesITCase
[INFO] Tests run: [...] Time elapsed: 0.91 s - in [*].RegionsITCase
[INFO] Tests run: [...] Time elapsed: 16.238 s - in [*].SirenCommunauxITCase
[INFO] Tests run: [...] Time elapsed: 1.043 s - in [*].DepartementsITCase
[INFO] Tests run: [...] Time elapsed: 2.855 s - in [*].EvenementsCommunauxITCase
[ERROR] Tests run: [...] Time elapsed: 61.191 s <<< FAILURE! - in [*].GroupementsPerimetresITCase
[INFO] Tests run: [...] Time elapsed: 258.096 s - in CogSuiteIT

Not only the execution order isn't the one I am expecting,
{CommunesITCase, RegionsITCase, SirenCommunauxITCase, DepartementsITCase, EvenementsCommunauxITCase}
≠ {RegionsITCase, DepartementsITCase, SirenCommunauxITCase, CommunesITCase, EvenementsCommunauxITCase}

but these tests looks also run twice, as CogSuiteIT is marked as run too.

What the best way to solve this problem?

answers.body:
I'm sorry to have asked a question that is a bit confuse. I've found it's solution eventually.

  • exclude **/IT*.java when executing surefire plugin so that *IT tests classes aren't taken into account by it
  • exclude **/*ITCase*.java when executing failsafe and renaming test classes that are engaged in a suite with that suffix ITCase.java.

It looks complex, and I'm sorry because it is a bit, yes, but this allow me to have:

  • In normal compilation (without -Passemblage profile) only test units run, by surefire (no IT classes at all)

  • In assembly/integration testing (with -Passemblage):

    • all tests of *IT classes files, but *ITCase
    • all tests of my suites run too, but once, as the classes ran by the suite are named with ITCase and cannot be launched alone a second time.

In this project it allows me to execute:

  • some modules having integration tests ordered by a suite: here or here
  • some modules having integration tests not ordered by a suite
  • some modules having only unit tests
 mvn install -Passemblage -fn |  grep -F 'Tests run'

question_comments.body: @khmarbaise sorry, everything was confuse and complex. I've found the solution I was searching for and posted it as an answer. I hope it will clarify all.

So first I would question why using suites at all... and if you name the "tests" which are used by your Suite not following the naming conventions they will not being executed by default only by your suites... What does that mean "30+ modules to test" ? Each module has it's own tests? Can you create an example project on Github or alike is easier to see the real setup...
@khmarbaise I have 30+ modules to test, many having test cases in *ITCase.java files. One suite will run 37 test methods among 7 ITCase files, for example.

Based on what I can understand from your question, if you are looking to run a specified test and only that, you can use the failsafe plugin's user property it.test. See also: maven.apache.org/surefire/maven-failsafe-plugin/examples/…
In Surefieplugin you don't need to execlude *IT.java because that is the default...furthermore failsafeplugin has an option "skipITs' ... maven.apache.org/surefire/maven-failsafe-plugin/…

If you use a Suite which references tests which itself are named as tests that means they will be executed by the suite as well as from surefire/failsafe pllugin... I would ask why using Suites? To select a suite just execute mvn command and give the name of Suite that will execute only the suite and it's referenced test...The execution order is usually not defined ?

79672215.body: exclude **/IT*.java when executing surefire plugin so that *IT tests classes aren't taken into account by it ... IT's are excluded by default from surefire-plugin because surefire is for unit tests with different naming schema... maven-failsafe-plugin is intended to run integration tests... based on the naming schema *IT.java etc... check the maven.apache.org/surefire/maven-surefire-plugin/… while maven.apache.org/surefire/maven-failsafe-plugin/…
